reviewText: As a millenial, I grew up on Humongous Entertainment games and was excited to see that they are re-releasing many of their old titles. Spy Fox was just charming as I remember it. I especially enjoyed picking up on a lot of the humor I missed as a child. My only complaint is that the voice actors, for reasons I cannot comprehend, are different. And they're just not getting it. If, like me, you played the original game enough to memorize all the nuances and inflections of the dialogue, the new voice acting will prove lackluster, irksome, and at times, distracting. Nonetheless, playing spy fox was a great nostalgic kick and I look forward to rediscovering more of the HE re-releases.

reviewText:
Let's get one thing out of the way before I continue; if you have any prior interest in Spy Fox, it's because you played these games as a kid. If you're playing these without any kind of nostalgic background, you won't have the same experience.

That said, however, the first installment in the Spy Fox series seems to disprove the notion that nostalgia is a crap-covered filter. Yes, it's still a kids' game at heart, but it's doused in a comic book art style and brimming with amusing one-liners and real-world references; the majority of which flew right over my head as a kid. Humongous made kids' games that had some damn good writing, and Spy Fox: Dry Cereal is a prime example. It never wanders into subtle adult references the way Pixar does, but the cultural references got many a chuckle out of me.

If anything, the game is too-filled with good writing. The titular character is suave, and his brand of humor is dry as a desert, but he has a habit of delivering one-liners any time he enters or prepares to leave an area. The writing itself never gets grating, but having the game hampered down by dialogue so often, especially when backtracking, can get annoying at times. Also potentially annoying are the puzzles. Most of them, I remembered from playing the game as a kid.

The solutions are by no means Monkey-Island level of crazy, and you won't be doing pixel-hunting, but your hand is never really held as you progress You space out during a cutscene and you've got to do a bit of memory recall. Not to mention, I have no idea how a kid could figure out some of these puzzles.

However, these are minor complaints. Spy Fox isn't a hard game"
date: and even if it slows down every so often to deliver oddly-choreographed dialogue
recommended: you're not going to grow increasingly impatient with it. The art style is fun
hoursPlayed: the writing is mature yet still kid-friendly
voteText: and the game's collective parody of spy culture is refreshing and appreciated. Heck
helpfulPercent: even if you didn't play this as a kid

reviewText:
What a masterpiece.

You'll be blown away by the gripping story, with plot twists at every turn.

The revolutionary gameplay is some of the most realistic the genre has ever seen, with amazing AI, and beautiful MS paint graphics.

While the FPS mechanics were kind of lacking, the gunplay was still very entertaining, and the sound design helped with the action, helping you pick out enemies based on sound. The quicktime events were also placed at the right moments, it made you feel like you were actually knocking on a door.

A great game for everyone, just wished they would have added more of the Horror elements that are displayed in the Putt-Putt games, but it's amazing overall.  10/10 would buy/play

reviewText:
The first PC game I owned, and the one I played the most as a kid on the family computer.

I was overjoyed to see that the Humongous Entertainment games we're released on steam, and immediately bought the few I could remember playing. This game is built upon nothing but James Bond references and parodies, and in saying that, it still has a great feel. The game changes each time you play it, and on a lonely day, I played through it some 7 times in a row, and I was still getting unique combinations of four or five different puzzles.
As games stand today, I don't know if it would hold up comparatively to AAA point and click adventure games, like the Walking Dead Game, but it is a good game. (or I'm a crazy shell of a person, bending solely on the whim of nostalgia)
voteText: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: As a nostalgia trip this game is great. It still has some humor that's on point. Even sitting here at 23 I can still enjoy parts of this game just like when I was 8.  It's a very simplistic point and click that does have a few creative puzzles here and there. It can easily be finished in around 2 or 3 hours. I did it in just under 2. The only gripe I have with it is how long it takes to get from area to area. Spy Fox loves to do some pointless animations/ramble on about things everytime you enter certain rooms. Traveling across 5 screens should only take about 10 seconds but in Spy Fox it can take upwards of a minute! It will definitely get on your nerves after a while. Outside of that, it's Spy Fox. Unless you grew up with this or know someone younger who might enjoy this then there is really no other reason to get this. It's a pure nostalgia rush. Nothing more, nothing less.

reviewText:
I may have nostalgia in one eye (probably both), but this game is still as good as it ever was.

For anyone who has not played this game since the 90s, it's definitely worth a playthrough or two. Everything is the same as its original release, including all the voice actors. That being said, if you still have your CD copy of the game, there's nothing more to be found here beyond the convenience of Steam. The only added difference I could find during my playthrough was that Spacebar now pauses the game.

All this being said, I only recommend this game to those who want the nostalgia factor, or if the purchase is for a child. You'll be able to blaze through the whole story (one variant at least) in a half hour or less. If you use the Esc key, probably 10 minutes or less on a bad day. However, the game is meant for children, and I was certainly stuck at parts for quite a while as a child.

reviewText: I used to play this game all the time when I was a little kid. I loved the theme and the cute spy story. Yeah everyone's a furry but it's not that big of a deal. It's replay ability is also very high, considering elements in the story change every time you play it. Some times you're going to have to find out how to tango with the russian enemy spy cat, some times play a highstakes game of go fish. It's childish but a great stetiotipical spy story. Also the nostalgia of playing this again after so many years was through the roof. Only complaint I had was the mouse was kinda buggy, enough so that is was fairly distracting.\n\n8/10 If you've played Spy Fox as a kid like me, you'll definitely love it.

2. The game runs in Slow machine mode" by default

reviewText:
This is a bit of a tough recommend, since I grew up with Spy Fox as a child. Much like Pajama Sam, I had to take off my rose-tinted nostalgia glasses to really look at this game and...

...Yeah, I don't like it as much as I used to.

Just because I have a thumbs down on your favorite childhood game doesn't mean you should instantly dislike my review. I'm going to go into detailed reasons why I don't like Spy Fox as much now. I'm not saying I hate this game, I just don't see it as this incredibly entertaining game anymore, since I'm- you know- an adult.

Spy Fox follows the James Bond parody of... Spy Fox, as he investigates a mysterious Greek island to uncover a secret villain's plot involving stealing... all the milk... then flooding the earth... so the cows get blamed... and then they'll get arrested, which means no more cow milk... then he'll get rich selling goat milk.

What the hell?

I understand most people will say, It's made for kids!" to which I reply
date: "Why are you making excuses for bad story-telling?". I like a good deal of movies and video games out there
recommended: and  I enjoy just as many products made for children. I like Avatar: The Last Airbender
voteText: and Pajama Sam #1 because they were made for kids
helpfulPercent: but also had adults in mind while they were making their stories. I never expect the most perfect story ever
votesHelpful: but at least some sense of logic would be appreciated.\n\nOn top of that
votesTotal: Spy Fox's voice was very... annoying to me. It didn't bother me as much when I was seven
commentsCount: every time he breaks the game by saying a really dumb pun just immediately makes me sigh and roll my eyes. He's supposed to be charming and witty
column16: but he comes across as the nerd in school who thinks its funny to have your jokes revolve around the same topic or remain the same type of joke.\n\nThe actual gameplay is pretty meh. It's a Humongous game
column17: so you know what's in store. Lots of clicking. But the story remains the same
column18: with only two distinct variations between achieving your final goal
column19: and three random keys to the M.W.D. (Milky Weapon of Destruction) that you'll have to solve one per game.\n\nThat
column20: and there's oftentimes some annoying backtracking. Especially if you want to defeat the Kawk-a-Doodle Foo guy
column21: you have to go ALL the way back to the cafe (Yes
column22: I mispelled C-O-C-K-a-Doodle Foo on purpose. I hate being forcibly censored). If you forget one spy gadget
column23: you have to return to the MobCo base
column24: and grab that gadget in order to advance.\n\nTo me this game
column25: seems significantly less developed than Pajama Sam. I mean
column27: but there was a sense of exploring an entirely new world. It was beautiful to look at and to discover the three missing items in it. In Spy Fox
column28: the island is colored with different greys
column30: and puke greens. It's just not very appealing to look at. And you stay in the city/ocean/secret base almost the whole game. The only time you get to see more of the island is when you're driving
column31: and even then it's not much.\n\nPajama Sam also had structure to it
column32: but it was flexible enough for there to be nine different variations of games. Spy Fox has about six. Again
column34: but it feels severely more limited when the only difference between playthroughs is whether you go out to sea or drive
column35: and which key you'll be grabbing this time. It doesn't feel like I'm a spy. It feels like I'm going through the motions. And that might be because I've beaten this game a ton as a kid.\n\nBesides that
column36: there are plenty of good things in this game. There's tons of little references to James Bond and even a ton of things that have nothing to do with spies. Fox says
column38: I've got your number!" at one point
column39: which I thought was cute. The actual animals living in this world stick out a lot and are both very well-drawn and colored. You can tell that two different people worked on the backgrounds and characters- or perhaps it was the same guy with two different ideas in mind.\n\nThat
column40: and I like the gadget and question system. Being able to hold onto 4 gadget at a time for whatever might pop up is really practical
column41: as is gathering questions about characters and asking people about them.\n\nPlus
column42: the game does a good job at making you feel like a spy. From playing "Go Fish!"
column43: to arming a missile system to blow up a door
column44: to laser-cutting through a door- the game makes sure you feel like a secret agent on a mission.\n\nBut
column46: for kids. Whatever.\n\nWhile its charm has worn on me
column47: it certainly hasn't for the rabid Humongous fans out there. I still enjoyed playing through it
column48: but I just feel like it's not as good as how I remember it. I do remember having much fonder memories of Spy Fox 3
column49: and we'll see if that still carries. But my final score for Spy Fox in Dry Cereal is a 5/10. To me
column50: the pros in this game pretty much equal the cons."

reviewText: If you played this game as a kid, you won't regret replaying it as an adult. The writing and voice work are excellent, the art and animation are great (despite the low resolution) - for a kid's game at its time it was way ahead of the game. You'll see how much you missed as a kid (the PUNS, the REFERENCES, and the JUST PLAIN FUNNY STUFF THAT YOU DIDN'T GET BECAUSE OF UNDERDEVELOPED VOCABULARY). This game is awesome and hilarious. I think I'm enjoying it more, in fact, than I did as a child. I'm clicking on everything, because I want to hear every piece of dialogue (there are about three witty phrases for everything you click on). Also, the story changes every time you replay, into three(?) randomized configurations, AND they just made the UK version available to everyone (which I hear is just as funny, if not funnier, than the US version). Replayability is sky-rocketting.\nJust buy it. Play it. And don't reconsider the purchase until then. Like I said, you don't be disappointed.

reviewText: If you have never heard of this, then you had a terrible childhood. Life is not complete without Spy Fox or any game that was made by this game company. I remember raging when I was stuck in any Spy Fox game, and I still rage today about parts that I, now a 21 year old get stuck at. It is a blow to my self-esteem, but hey, I rage at the same parts I got stuck in when I was little.\n\nThat pig will never take any more of my trinkets away from me. I. Will. Win.

reviewText: This game brings back a lot of memories...I've now played all the Spy Fox games and this one is by far my favorite. If you were to choose out of the 3 available I would recommend this one above the rest. Entertaining/cheesy dialogue, fun puzzles (although not hard at all, considering this game is aimed at a younger demographic) and fairly replayable. Additionally there's a  fun side game, Go-Fish"."

reviewText: The best part of this simple point-and-click adventure is the witty dialogue. It's a game for children, but so much of the dialogue is surprisingly sophisticated with puns galore. You have to save the world's milk supply from a goat named William the Kid. You are transported onto the Island of Acidophilus. You have to enlist the help of a cow named Howard Hugh Heifer. And the puns go on.\n\nWithin the game, you have to use specific spy gadgets or items at specific points in the story. And the story actually changes somewaht on subsequent playthroughs, which is neat. It's all so light-hearted that I can't help but feel like a kid while playing the game.

reviewText:
The game of ultimate nostalgia.

Spy Fox is a great game and only takes a couple hours (at most) to beat. It's so awesome to be able to replay a game that I used to play when I was a child. A wonderful blast-to-the-past game that you can play in your free time. C:

Also, you're a fox in a SUIT, who gets to play GoFish with a giant pig, and dance the tango with a beautiful feline. How awesome is that?!

reviewText:
Spy fox in Dry Cereal is the first in the triology from my younger childhood. A great sense of nostalgia and a whole lot of fun.

Pros:
1.Puzzles were always interesting. Whether you were knockin aligators unconcious with the power of food or solving lazer-mirror puzzles they were always fun. As a teen now with a little bit of rememberance puzzles were easier but still fun.
2.Interesting gameplay mechanics. One aspect of the game was interrogating characters about other characters for information. Timed minigames were also thrown in causing some trouble to even the older of players. Gadgets are interesting and fun.
3.There are 2 endings. I've only completed one as of now. So I'll be back after completing the rest of the series again.
4.Humor. There are lots of puns, jokes, and James Bond references of which I was quite fond of. Also WANNA SEE MY TATTOO

Cons:
1: Go Fish. Really the only con. Go Fish was one of the minigames. Basically I bought a Jar of Trinkets and used them to gamble with this fat pig. We had to play Go Fish. I swear that pig had a dwarf hiding in the one sided mirror disco ball feeding him info on my card stack with a earpiece. Either that or he was psychic. Too many frustrating tries came out of this. Also guess what your reward is. Nothing. You get jack ♥♥♥♥! It was supposed to be a fun minigame but it was not fun. So if you play this game. Stay away from the ♥♥♥♥ing pig. There's no point to deal with annoyance. Edit: Nevermind what I said. You have to beat him in one of the paths.

Story:
This time Spy Fox is up against William The Kid. He's a goat who wants to steal all the cow milk right from their udders.
How does he plan to carry this heinous deed out?
Well first he kidnaps Mr. Udderly, a cow that milks cows for milk... What the ♥♥♥♥ mate. That's like me farming woman's ♥♥♥♥ for milk so I can sell it to lil kids. Oh ♥♥♥♥ I think that is a real thing.
Anyway he then plans to flood the world with all the milk so that he can send out tsunamis of the milk onto the world to kill everyone.
Then he'll point his finger at the cows blaming them for it so they end up in jail. These cows will have to deal with Prison ♥♥♥♥ for the rest of their lives. Taking it in the backside in Alcatraz for an eternity.
Then he'll make everyone drink goat's milk. Which honestly the last part doesn't sound half bad. I quite like Goat Cheese.
Anyway like usual you and your fursona: Spy Fox have to stop him.
To do so we must turn of his Milky Weapon Of Destruction (Sounds like a killer name for a ♥♥♥♥. Kappa.), free the cows, and throw this goat ♥♥♥♥♥ into Alcatraz!
It's fun.
Play it especially if you played it as a child and are looking for a nostalgasm. If you're a furry then maybe this is the game for you.
voteText: No ratings yet 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
In this gripping tale of espionage and conspiracy, you play as one Agent Spy Fox, top notch secret agent and lady's man. You are sent on a mission to Acidophilus island to investigate the strange disappearance of the entire world's milk supplies. On this island, you must search for clues and speak to the natives to find out who committed this heinous crime.
+Solid Gameplay
+Gripping Storyline
+Very fun minigames
+Many interesting puzzles

- Kind of short
overall 9/10 its gud

reviewText: This takes me back, I used to play this game with my sister all the time, but I lost the CD. Thanks.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Playing this game brought a smile to my face. It was like reliving a bit of my childhood all over again—only this time, I actually played the game all the way through and understood what was going on!

Spy Fox was still very engaging and entertaining. I enjoyed the humor and the lines that definitely went over my head when I was a kid.

I recommend it to anyone who feels like tapping into their inner kid again and enjoying a bit of that nostalgia that comes with games like this one.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Nice to see this game pop up again. It has that cheesey though amusing quality to it that I remember as a kid. The game's good for a chuckle, isn't too difficult to figure out, but has some smart writing. Multiple play-through options for completing it; it randomizes each time you start a new game. The VA work isn't too shabby for a PC game from 1997 (noticed that Professor Quack is voiced by the guy who does Bentley from Sly Cooper). Definitely good for the kiddies, or for an idiot like me -- a 24 year old looking for a smile to unwind after work.

reviewText: If you played this game as a kid, you won't regret replaying it as an adult. The writing and voice work are excellent, the art and animation are great (despite the low resolution) - for a kid's game at its time it was way ahead of the game. You'll see how much you missed as a kid (the PUNS, the REFERENCES, and the JUST PLAIN FUNNY STUFF THAT YOU DIDN'T GET BECAUSE OF UNDERDEVELOPED VOCABULARY). This game is awesome and hilarious. I think I'm enjoying it more, in fact, than I did as a child. I'm clicking on everything, because I want to hear every piece of dialogue (there are about three witty phrases for everything you click on). Also, the story changes every time you replay, into three(?) randomized configurations, AND they just made the UK version available to everyone (which I hear is just as funny, if not funnier, than the US version). Replayability is sky-rocketting.\nJust buy it. Play it. And don't reconsider the purchase until then. Like I said, you don't be disappointed.

reviewText: Nice retro game that reminds me of the Pajama Sam, Putt Putt and Freddi Fish games I loved as a kid. Still play them on rare occasions for the nostalgia. If I find all the games for cheap, I'd just buy them all on Steam.\nGet it! Some of it may be cheesy, the game may be outdated, but it is still great! Even more so for those who played Humongous Entertainment Games in their youth.

*Childhood relived*

Wow, what an amazing game. Really on par with the AAA games out there.
Fantastic Visual Novel
Sweet James Bond / Batman detective like skills and gadgets
What swag
Seriously Spy Fox drops puns like a gangster

Don't mess with Foxes
Appreciate the milk you have here today
Think of Spy Fox when you drink milk

Our hero: 9999999999/10
